awd_abstract_narration:
Fluids, such as air or water, support many different kinds of waves. For example, sound waves propagate through compressible fluids, water waves propagate on the surface of an ocean, and large-scale atmospheric waves affect the earth's weather and climate. At sufficiently low intensities, waves are modeled by linear systems of equations, which are relatively well-understood; but at higher intensities, the equations become nonlinear. Nonlinearity introduces fundamental mathematical difficulties and leads to new physical phenomena, such as the shock waves generated by supersonic aircraft, the solitons (particle-like waves) that propagate on shallow water, and nonlinear wave interactions that generate additional waves. The aim of this project is to study the dynamics of waves in fluids and uncover new nonlinear phenomena in the context of specific physical applications. This award will also provide support for the involvement of one graduate student in the project. 

This project addresses the mathematical modeling and analysis of nonlinear wave propagation in a variety of fluid systems. It focuses on the asymptotic analysis of nonlinear, nondispersive and dispersive waves, including waves that propagate on boundaries, free surfaces, or interfaces. A unifying framework is provided by Hamiltonian dynamics, which is an essential structure for the waves considered in the proposed research. Physical applications include waves on vorticity discontinuities in incompressible fluids, temperature fronts in surface quasi-geostrophic flows, current-vortex sheets in plasmas, shock wave reflection, and the resonant interaction of sound and entropy waves. A number of these problems lead to common mathematical themes, such as degenerate dispersive shocks, normal form transformations for quasilinear wave equations, and the formation and propagation of singularities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fluids, such as water or air, support many different kinds of waves. Perhaps the most familiar examples are water waves on the surface of the ocean and sound waves in air. At low intensities, the waves are described by linear equations, and they can be analyzed by decomposing a general wave motion into a superposition of fundamental modes. At higher intensities, the waves are described by nonlinear equations. Nonlinear waves are much harder to analyze than linear waves, and completely new nonlinear effects arise. Examples include the breaking of water waves and the presence of shock waves in the sound waves generated by supersonic aircraft. This project is concerned with the effects of nonlinearity on waves in fluids.

The major results of the project are a continuing study of waves on one type of fluid interface. A primary physical example is an interface, or front, separating two regions with different constant vorticities in an ideal incompressible fluid flow. (The vorticity measures the local angular velocity of the fluid.) In contrast to highly unstable vortex sheets, where the vorticity is concentrated on the interface, these vorticity discontinuities are linearly stable and support surface waves that propagate along them. The effects of nonlinearity on these waves is remarkably complex, and the interface eventually breaks, throwing off many, extremely thin filaments. Previous work had indicated, without proof, that the oscillatory motion of interfaces with small slopes greatly delays the time it takes for the interface to break. This project provided a proof of the delayed wave-breaking, and it also proved that the motion of the interface is well-described before wave-breaking by a Burgers-Hilbert equation, which provides a clear picture of its nonlinear dynamics.

The incompressible fluid interfaces described above are a special case of a family of interface problems. A second physically significant example is an interface between two different constant temperatures in surface quasi-geostrophic flows. Quasi-geostrophic fluid flows are the primary flows in the atmosphere where the Coriolis force (due to the earth's rotation) and the pressure force almost balance. Surface quasi-geostrophic (SQG) flows arise when quasi-geostrophic flows are confined to the surface of the earth. This project provided a careful derivation of SQG front equations that describe the propagation of waves along temperature discontinuities in surface quasi-geostrophic flows, justifying an earlier heuristic derivation of these equations. In addition, it developed a proof that, for localized disturbances of planar SQG-interfaces with sufficiently small slope, the waves spread out sufficiently rapidly that the interface never breaks.

The previous wave motions are special cases of a family of interface problems that can be described by generalized surface quasi-geostrophic (GSQG) front equations. Other results of the project are the completion of a proof that localized, small-slope disturbances of planar GSQG-interfaces never break for all relevant cases in the family, as well as the derivation and analysis of equations that describe the coupled motion of two fronts in all of these cases.
